description:
Israel and Iran have been trading attacks on each other for a week including, for the first time, attacks on each other's territory. Will Israel's latest retaliation be the end of this wave of hostilities, or will Iranian response bring the long-standing enemies closer to all-out war? We hear from NPR's national security correspondent and our correspondent in Israel.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates
title: Israel Strikes Back at Iran, Will This Calm or Inflame Tensions?

description: The modern study of the starvation was sparked by the liberation of concentration camp survivors. U.S. and British soldiers rushed to feed them — and yet they sometimes perished.
title: What World War II taught us about how to help starving people today

description: The new rules also broaden the interpretation of Title IX to cover pregnant, gay and transgender students. They do not address whether schools can ban trans athletes from women's and girls' teams.
title: Biden administration adds Title IX protections for LGBTQ students, assault victims

description: Mikael Petrosyan of Children's National Hospital says gun violence against children is preventable.
title: 'We created this problem:' a pediatric surgeon on how gun violence affects children

description: During his decades-long career, MacNeil reported on the Kennedy assassination, the Cuban missile crisis and the fall of the Berlin Wall. He died April 12. Originally broadcast in 1986 and 1995.
title: Remembering Robert MacNeil, longtime host of PBS 'NewsHour'

description: Accelerator pedals on the new Cybertrucks can get stuck, a potentially dangerous production flaw.  The reason why they're so sticky is soap.
title: Tesla recalls Cybertruck over sticky problem. Blame it on — yes — soap

description: Twenty-six hotels that already have permits can move forward, but after that a hotel can only be built if one shuts down. Tourists spent about 20.7 million nights in Amsterdam hotels last year.
title: Amsterdam was flooded with tourists in 2023, so it won't allow any more hotels

description: Israel has launched a strike against Iran, a U.S. official tells NPR. Taylor Swift's highly anticipated "Tortured Poets Department" is here.
title: Israel strikes Iran, U.S. official says; Taylor Swift's 'Tortured Poets' is here

description: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan's District Attorney, has great friends and determined critics
title: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan's district attorney, draws friends close and critics closer

description: In other news, the WNBA draft was haute, a star system is hot and a Nike uniform was deemed neither haute nor hot.
title: What's going to explode in space? Find out in the quiz

description: The federal government is investing billions to bolster school safety and mental health resources to combat gun violence. But some sense a disconnect between those programs and what students need.
title: Where gun violence is common, some students say physical safety is a top concern

description: Public health authorities are investigating reports of counterfeit injections sickening 19 people across nine states. Experts say getting bona fide Botox starts with finding a trustworthy provider.
title: Fake Botox has sickened patients nationwide. Here's what to know — and what to avoid

description: The House bills largely mirror a foreign aid package that passed the Senate in February, with aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. The House has an additional bill targeting Iran, China and Russia.
title: Here's what's in the House foreign aid bills

description: Many users are concealing their public photos and sharing instead in private spaces. It's something of a protest against the over-sharing culture of social media. And Gen Z is driving the trend.
title: The Rise of 'Grid Zero': Why more Instagram users are hiding their profile

description: Where did the idea come from that individuals, rather than corporations, should keep the world litter-free? What history is hidden in the trash? Find out here.
title: Who created the idea of litter – and why? Play this month's Throughline history quiz.

description:
Earlier this week, pro-Palestinian protestors blocked traffic on highways and bridges in San Francisco, Chicago, New York and Seattle. On that same day, the Supreme Court made it incredibly difficult to protest in a lot of the American South. In this episode, host Brittany Luse looks at the state of protest in America. She sits down with Sandhya Dirks, an NPR reporter who covers race and identity, and Elizabeth Blair, a senior arts reporter at NPR. Together, they discuss shifting attitudes towards protest as well as new anti-protest legislation. Then, they play a game of But Did You Know?

After that, we take a look back at OJ Simpson and his impact on culture. Brittany is joined by NPR's Mandalit Del Barco and Eric Deggans to hear their account of how OJ shifted media and television as we know it. He's had an outsized influence on everything from true-crime, to TMZ, to the Kardashians.
title: The backlash against protests; plus, how OJ Simpson changed media forever

description: With Democratic support, the legislation overcomes a major procedural hurdle and is expected to head to a weekend vote by the full House.
title: House foreign aid bills advance with Democrats' help; Johnson may still be in peril
